qas.question: Which part is larger relative to the brain in primates?
Which non-primate has the ability to learn and perform new task?
Mammals with smaller brains tend to be in what class in the food chain?
What part of the brain is larger in rats compared to the rest of the brain?
With primates, what is related to intelligence?

plausible_answers.text: the ability to learn, matched with behavioral flexibility

qas.question: What are two indications of a larger cerebrum?
What are cats able to do when they find a new home?

plausible_answers.text: must think to outwit its prey

qas.question: What is one thing that shows a cat has a large cerebrum?

context: In intelligent mammals, such as primates, <b3_0>the <a0_0>cerebrum<b3_0/><a0_0/> is larger relative to the rest of the brain. Intelligence itself is not easy to define, but indications of intelligence include <b5_0>the ability to learn, matched with behavioral flexibility<b5_0/>. <a1_0>Rats<a1_0/>, for example, are considered to be highly intelligent, as they can <b6_0>learn and perform new tasks<b6_0/>, an ability that may be important when they first colonize a fresh habitat. In some mammals, <b4_0>food gathering<b4_0/> appears to be related to intelligence: a deer feeding on plants has a brain smaller than a cat, which <b7_0>must think to outwit its <a2_0>prey<b7_0/><a2_0/>.
